title: Lymph Node & Spleen
subject: Histology
description: Questions on the structure, function, and histology of lymph nodes and the spleen.

questions.questionText: Which structure forms the stroma of the lymph node?
questions.explanation: The stroma of the lymph node consists of the capsule, trabeculae, and reticular network.

questions.questionText: What distinguishes primary cortical nodules from secondary cortical nodules in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Secondary cortical nodules contain germinal centers, while primary nodules do not.

questions.questionText: Which zone in the lymph node is thymus-dependent?
questions.explanation: The paracortex contains T-lymphocytes and is the thymus-dependent zone.

questions.questionText: What lines the cortical sinuses of lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Cortical sinuses are lined by endothelial cells and macrophages.

questions.questionText: Where are medullary cords located?
options: In the medulla of lymph nodes
questions.correctAnswer: In the medulla of lymph nodes
questions.explanation: Medullary cords are elongated aggregations of lymphocytes in the medulla.

questions.questionText: Which cells are predominant in the germinal centers of lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Germinal centers contain activated lymphocytes, lymphoblasts, and plasmablasts.

questions.questionText: What is the path of lymph circulation through a lymph node?
options: Efferent vessels → medullary sinuses → cortical sinuses
Afferent vessels → cortical sinuses → medullary sinuses → efferent vessels
questions.correctAnswer: Afferent vessels → cortical sinuses → medullary sinuses → efferent vessels
questions.explanation: Lymph enters via afferent vessels, flows through cortical and medullary sinuses, then exits via efferent vessels at the hilum.

questions.questionText: Which structure in the spleen is composed of Billroth cords and sinusoids?
questions.explanation: Red pulp consists of splenic cords (Billroth cords) and sinusoids.

questions.questionText: What type of epithelium lines post-capillary venules in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Post-capillary venules are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium with receptors for lymphocyte homing.

questions.questionText: Which theory explains splenic circulation as a combination of open and closed pathways?
questions.explanation: The combined theory states that circulation is open when relaxed and closed when contracted.

questions.questionText: What is the primary function of the spleen's white pulp?
questions.explanation: White pulp contains lymphocytes for immune functions.

questions.questionText: Which component of the spleen's stroma contains smooth muscle?
questions.explanation: The splenic capsule contains collagen fibers, fibroblasts, and smooth muscles.

questions.questionText: Which cells are abundant in the splenic cords of Billroth?
questions.explanation: Splenic cords contain RBCs, WBCs, lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages.

questions.questionText: What is the outermost zone of the white pulp in the spleen called?
questions.explanation: The marginal zone is the outermost layer of the white pulp.

questions.questionText: Which structure in the spleen is thymus-dependent?
questions.explanation: The peri-arteriolar lymph sheath (PALS) is the thymus-dependent zone in the spleen.

questions.questionText: What is the primary function of the spleen's red pulp?
questions.explanation: Red pulp filters blood and removes old RBCs.

questions.questionText: Which cells line the medullary sinuses of lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Medullary sinuses are lined by endothelial cells and macrophages.

questions.questionText: Which structure carries lymph away from the lymph node?
questions.explanation: Efferent vessels exit at the hilum, carrying filtered lymph away.

questions.questionText: What is the main component of the reticular network in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: The reticular network is made of reticular fibers, stained with silver (Ag).

questions.questionText: Which part of the spleen is responsible for destroying old RBCs?
questions.explanation: Red pulp contains macrophages that phagocytize aged RBCs.

questions.questionText: Which fibers are primarily found in the lymph node capsule?
questions.explanation: The capsule is composed of collagen fibers and fibroblasts.

questions.questionText: What stain is used to visualize the reticular network in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Reticular networks are stained with silver (Ag) due to their reticular fiber composition.

questions.questionText: Which cells are primarily found in the paracortex of lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: The paracortex is the thymus-dependent zone rich in T-lymphocytes.

questions.questionText: Where are trabeculae most irregularly arranged in a lymph node?
questions.explanation: Trabeculae are regular in the cortex but irregular in the medulla.

questions.questionText: Which structure is unique to the spleen's red pulp?
questions.explanation: Billroth cords, containing RBCs and macrophages, are specific to the red pulp.

questions.questionText: What is the primary role of macrophages in lymph node sinuses?
questions.explanation: Macrophages in sinuses filter lymph by phagocytizing debris and pathogens.

questions.questionText: Which organ contains both afferent and efferent lymphatic vessels?
questions.explanation: Lymph nodes have afferent (entering) and efferent (exiting) vessels; the spleen lacks afferent lymphatics.

questions.questionText: Which structure in the spleen is associated with central arterioles?
questions.explanation: The peri-arteriolar lymph sheath (PALS) surrounds central arterioles in the white pulp.

questions.questionText: What is the primary function of post-capillary venules in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Post-capillary venules have receptors to guide lymphocyte migration into the node.

questions.questionText: Which component of the spleen's stroma contains smooth muscle?
questions.explanation: Splenic trabeculae contain collagen, fibroblasts, and smooth muscle.

questions.questionText: Which cells are absent in the germinal centers of lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Germinal centers contain immune cells but not RBCs, which are filtered in the spleen.

questions.questionText: What distinguishes splenic sinusoids from regular capillaries?
questions.explanation: Splenic sinusoids have fenestrated endothelial cells and discontinuous basement membranes.

questions.questionText: Which artery supplies blood to the spleen?
questions.explanation: The splenic artery branches from the celiac trunk and enters at the hilum.

questions.questionText: Which zone of the spleen's white pulp contains follicular B-cells?
questions.explanation: The follicular zone in white pulp is rich in B-lymphocytes.

questions.questionText: What is the final destination of lymph after exiting a lymph node?
questions.explanation: Filtered lymph exits via efferent vessels, eventually returning to the bloodstream.

questions.questionText: Which organ is responsible for fetal hematopoiesis?
questions.explanation: The spleen produces blood cells during fetal life but not in adulthood.

questions.questionText: Which structure is NOT part of the lymph node parenchyma?
questions.explanation: Trabeculae are stromal components, not parenchymal.

questions.questionText: What is the primary role of the spleen's marginal zone?
questions.explanation: The marginal zone filters antigens from blood for immune response initiation.

questions.questionText: Which cell type is abundant in both lymph node medullary sinuses and splenic cords?
questions.explanation: Macrophages are present in both locations for phagocytic functions.

questions.questionText: Which statement about the spleen's capsule is true?
questions.explanation: The splenic capsule is covered by peritoneum and contains smooth muscle.

questions.questionText: Which cells are primarily responsible for antibody production in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Plasma cells, derived from B-lymphocytes, secrete antibodies in lymph nodes.

questions.questionText: Which feature distinguishes the spleen's white pulp from its red pulp?
questions.explanation: White pulp surrounds central arterioles, while red pulp contains sinusoids and Billroth cords.

questions.questionText: What is the primary role of fibroblasts in lymph node stroma?
questions.explanation: Fibroblasts produce collagen fibers in the capsule and trabeculae.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT a function of the spleen?
questions.explanation: Bile production occurs in the liver, not the spleen.

questions.questionText: Where are primary cortical nodules typically located?
questions.explanation: Primary nodules are found in the outer cortex and lack germinal centers.

questions.questionText: Which structure allows lymphocytes to enter lymph nodes from the bloodstream?
questions.explanation: Lymphocytes migrate into nodes via post-capillary venules in the paracortex.

questions.questionText: What is the clinical consequence of splenectomy?
questions.explanation: The spleen filters blood-borne pathogens; its removal increases infection risk.

questions.questionText: Which cell type is abundant in both the red pulp and medullary sinuses?
questions.explanation: Macrophages phagocytize debris in both red pulp and medullary sinuses.

questions.questionText: Which structure is absent in the thymus but present in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Germinal centers form in lymph nodes during immune responses but not in the thymus.

questions.questionText: What is the primary component of the reticular network in both organs?
questions.explanation: Reticular fibers form the supportive network in lymph nodes and spleen.

questions.questionText: Which organ filters both lymph and blood?
questions.explanation: Lymph nodes filter lymph; the spleen filters blood.

questions.questionText: Which zone of the spleen contains dendritic cells for antigen presentation?
questions.explanation: The marginal zone has dendritic cells that capture blood-borne antigens.

questions.questionText: What is the primary histological difference between cortical and medullary sinuses?
questions.explanation: Cortical sinuses are near nodules; medullary sinuses lie between cords.

questions.questionText: Which cell type is NOT found in the germinal center?
questions.explanation: Erythrocytes are filtered in the spleen, not present in germinal centers.

questions.questionText: Which structure connects the splenic trabeculae to the capsule?
questions.explanation: Reticular fibers form a network linking trabeculae and capsule.

questions.questionText: What is the role of the splenic central arteriole?
questions.explanation: Central arterioles branch into white pulp, supplying lymphocytes.

questions.questionText: Which statement about lymph node medullary cords is true?
questions.explanation: Medullary cords contain plasma cells secreting antibodies.

questions.questionText: Which organ lacks afferent lymphatic vessels?
questions.explanation: The spleen receives blood via arteries, not afferent lymphatics.

questions.questionText: What is the primary histological stain for identifying reticular fibers?
questions.explanation: Reticular fibers stain black with silver (Ag) methods.

questions.questionText: Which structure is critical for lymphocyte recirculation?
questions.explanation: Lymphocytes enter nodes via these venules for immune surveillance.

questions.questionText: Which theory of splenic circulation suggests blood flows directly into sinusoids?
questions.explanation: The closed theory posits that penicillar arterioles connect directly to sinusoids.

questions.questionText: Which cell type is primarily responsible for antigen presentation in the marginal zone of the spleen?
questions.explanation: Dendritic cells in the marginal zone capture antigens to initiate immune responses.

questions.questionText: Which region of the lymph node is most enriched with B-lymphocytes?
questions.explanation: Cortical nodules (follicles) contain B-lymphocytes, especially in germinal centers.

questions.questionText: What is the primary histological feature distinguishing splenic red pulp from white pulp?
questions.explanation: Red pulp contains RBCs and macrophages, while white pulp is lymphoid tissue.

questions.questionText: Which condition is most associated with loss of splenic function?
questions.explanation: Splenectomy increases susceptibility to encapsulated bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae.

questions.questionText: Which structure is unique to the thymus but absent in lymph nodes and spleen?
questions.explanation: Hassall's corpuscles are thymic structures involved in T-cell maturation.

questions.questionText: What is the primary function of the peri-arteriolar lymph sheath (PALS)?
questions.explanation: PALS is a T-cell-rich region surrounding central arterioles in the spleen.

questions.questionText: Which cell type is absent in the normal red pulp of the spleen?
questions.explanation: Megakaryocytes are found in bone marrow; splenic red pulp filters blood, not produces platelets.

questions.questionText: Which histological feature helps distinguish lymph node medulla from cortex?
questions.explanation: Medullary cords are elongated lymphocyte aggregations unique to the medulla.

questions.questionText: Which enzyme is critical for breaking down hemoglobin in splenic macrophages?
questions.explanation: Heme oxygenase degrades heme from phagocytized RBCs into biliverdin.

questions.questionText: Which structure is a hallmark of chronic inflammation in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Sinus histiocytosis refers to macrophage proliferation in sinuses due to chronic antigen exposure.

questions.questionText: Which embryonic layer gives rise to the spleen?
questions.explanation: The spleen develops from mesenchymal cells in the dorsal mesogastrium (mesodermal origin).

questions.questionText: Which feature is common to both lymph node trabeculae and splenic trabeculae?
questions.explanation: Both contain collagen and fibroblasts, but splenic trabeculae also have smooth muscle.

questions.questionText: Which cell type is critical for maintaining the reticular network in lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Reticular cells produce and maintain the reticular fiber network.

questions.questionText: Which clinical finding is typical of hypersplenism?
questions.explanation: Hypersplenism leads to excessive destruction of blood cells, causing pancytopenia.

questions.questionText: Which structure allows lymphocytes to exit lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Efferent vessels carry filtered lymph and lymphocytes out of the node.

questions.questionText: Which staining method is used to identify collagen in the lymph node capsule?
questions.explanation: Masson's trichrome stains collagen blue, distinguishing it from muscle.

questions.questionText: Which immune response is primarily mediated by the spleen's white pulp?
questions.explanation: White pulp B-cells drive antibody production (humoral immunity).

questions.questionText: Which structure is most affected in hereditary spherocytosis?
questions.explanation: Abnormal RBCs are trapped and destroyed in the red pulp.

questions.questionText: Which feature is absent in the medulla of lymph nodes?
questions.explanation: Germinal centers are located in the cortex; medulla contains cords and sinuses.
